speakers.bio: Kirill has been doing professional client-side development over the last decade in a variety of UI toolkits and libraries that spanned Motif, MFC, VB, Ada, Delphi, Swing and SWT. Since 2009 he's been part of the Android team at Google. He has a particular interest in creating polished, responsive and well-behaving, user-facing applications that help the end users achieve their goals quickly and painlessly.
speakers.name: Kirill Grouchnikov

speakers.bio:
Babak Pahlavan leads Product Management for Google Analytics. He oversees product & strategy for Mobile Apps, Universal Analytics, Google Tag Manager and Integrations with AdWords, AdMob, YouTube among other aspects of the business. 

Prior to Google, he was the co-founder and CEO of Clever Sense, an analytical context-aware recommendation engine, which was acquired by Google in December of 2011. 

In 2012, Babak was selected as one of the 30 under 30 from Forbes in the technology category. Babak holds a masters degree in EE with focus on CS from Stanford University and Bachelors degree from from UC Berkeley in EE and CS.
speakers.name: Babak Pahlavan

speakers.bio: David is a software engineer at Google, working on the platform powering the Google Art Project. Prior to joining Google in 2011, he worked at Aldebaran Robotics doing computer vision.
speakers.name: David  Coz

speakers.bio:
Payal has been a Product Manager on the Google Crisis Response team since 2012. She has focused on bringing important public warnings to affected people by driving the adoption of CAP (Common Alerting Protocol) globally, integrating Public Alerts in everyday tools at scale and is actively working on making them accessible through the Public Alerts API. She has also helped lead company-wide responses to disasters such as Hurricane Sandy and Typhoon Yolanda.
Payal has a B.S. in Computer Engineering from University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and an M.B.A. from MIT Sloan School of Management.
speakers.name: Payal Patel

speakers.bio: Engineer-artist. Doer-dreamer. Scientific coach, mentor, taskmaster, technogeek. Caltech PhD in mechanical engineering. CNN Top 10 Thinker. The Verge 50. Former Director of DARPA. Captain of the ATAP pirate ship. Likes epic sh*t.
speakers.name: Regina Dugan

speakers.bio: Hirotaka manages the overall Google Play Japan Games and Apps business alliance partnership activities including domestic and global business development. In addition, he provides consulting services and supports several partners in the areas of mobile business and the partnership framework with the objective to create new business opportunities in the Japan market.
speakers.name: Hirotaka Yoshitsugu

speakers.bio:
Ray Kurzweil is one of the world’s leading inventors, thinkers, and futurists, with a thirty-year track record of accurate predictions. Called "the restless genius" by The Wall Street Journal and "the ultimate thinking machine" by Forbes magazine, Kurzweil was selected as one of the top entrepreneurs by Inc. magazine, which described him as the "rightful heir to Thomas Edison." PBS selected him as one of the "sixteen revolutionaries who made America."

Kurzweil was the principal inventor of the first CCD flat-bed scanner, the first omni-font optical character recognition, the first print-to-speech reading machine for the blind, the first text-to-speech synthesizer, the first music synthesizer capable of recreating the grand piano and other orchestral instruments, and the first commercially marketed large-vocabulary speech recognition. 

Among Kurzweil’s many honors, he is the recipient of the National Medal of Technology, was inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame, holds twenty honorary Doctorates, and honors from three U.S. presidents.

Ray has written five national best-selling books, including New York Times best sellers The Singularity Is Near (2005) and How To Create A Mind (2012). He is a Director of Engineering at Google heading up a team developing machine intelligence and natural language understanding.
speakers.name: Ray Kurzweil

speakers.bio: Nadya Direkova is a designer focused on speed of innovation and team-work that create simple, beautiful solutions for a global audience. She works as a Staff Designer and Design Evangelist at Google X, a new product lab at Google. To date, Nadya has run 60 design sprints at Google, including projects for Google [X], Chrome and Ads & Commerce.
speakers.name: Nadya Direkova

speakers.bio: Gabriella Levine is an artist and hardware designer interested in the relationship between technology and ecology. She creates sculptural and robotic works that mimic environmental phenomena and animal behavior. She studied Biology and Piano at Cornell University and Oberlin College, then worked doing Cancer Research at Albert Einstein College of Medicine before abandoning the lab for the outdoors to become a wildland fire-fighter based in Oregon. She holds a Masters degree in Design and Technology from ITP, Tisch School of the Arts, NYU. She is President of OSHWA (Open Source Hardware Association), and recently joined Google[x] on the Rapid Eval team.
speakers.name: Gabriella Levine

speakers.bio:
Google Software Engineer working on AdWords Frontend. Contributing and coding with Dart since it's beginnings. Contributor to Angular.dart, mondo_dart wrappers, fukiya, formler, web-ui (now deprecated.)

Avid bicyclist, soccer & golf player, hockey and baseball enthusiast. Born and raised in the Silicon Valley.
speakers.name: Ted Sander

speakers.bio: Tomer Sharon is a Senior User Experience Researcher at Google Search in New York City. He is the author of the book, "Lean User Research for Product Development (Rosenfeld Media, 2015) and, "It’s Our Research" (2012). He is a startup mentor at Google’s Campus in Tel Aviv, Israel. Tomer founded and led the Israeli chapter of the User Experience Professionals' Association. He holds a master’s degree in Human Factors in Information Design from Bentley University in Waltham, MA.
speakers.name: Tomer Sharon

speakers.bio: For the last 22 years, and after earning his Ph.D. in cognitive psychology and user interface design, building innovative, top-of-the-line UX solutions and applications has been his passion. Before becoming an independent consultant, he co-founded two companies: the largest company in Israel for UX design (UI Ltd.) and Applied Cognitive Engineering, Ltd. (ACE) for cognitive training. Currently, in addition to his work as strategic UX consultant, he coordinates the UX activity for Campus TLV Launchpad, an acceleration program for startups, managed by Google in Tel Aviv and lecture at events across the globe.
speakers.name: Jacob Greenshpan

speakers.bio:
Paul Rohde is an engineer in Ads and an author on the AngularDart project.

Since the time I could walk I was always making something. I grew up cutting resistors in my dads basement, building robots out of legos, catapults in the garage and roller coasters out of k'nex. I am driven to to figure things out. I haven't climbed mount everest. I haven't been cliff diving or changed the world. But one day, I'm going to try.
speakers.name: Paul Rohde

speakers.bio:
Bob is a product designer based in Mountain View, CA. He currently works on the Glass design team.

At Google, he has led the user experience team for Google Glass, Emerging Markets product design, design strategy for YouTube, and interaction design for AdSense.
speakers.name: Bob Ryskamp

speakers.bio: Anwar Ghuloum is Engineering Manager for Android's Runtimes & Tools team at Google.  Prior to joining Google, Anwar was Director of Mobile Compute and Computer Vision at Nvidia, a Principal Engineer at Intel in the role of Chief Architect and Product Development Manager for Intel Array Building Blocks (formerly called Ct) in Intel Labs and the Software and Services Group, and a co-founder in a digital imaging chip startup and developed drug design software using 3D object recognition algorithms. Anwar holds a B.Sci. from UCLA  and a Ph.D. from Carnegie Mellon University, both in Computer Science.
speakers.name: Anwar Ghuloum

speakers.bio: I am a UX and Motion Designer on Chrome. I also do Sound Design across Google, including Doodles! Before Chrome, I worked on the Self-Driving Car User Experience. I love to build interactive prototypes, teach kids coding and electronics, and practice Wing Chun kung fu.
speakers.name: Manuel Clément

speakers.bio: I am a research scientist and team lead for physical interaction research at Google. We use the rich sensors of consumer devices -- such as their cameras, microphones and motion sensors -- to make user interaction more direct, intuitive and enjoyable. After receiving my PhD in Computer Science from Freiburg University, Germany, in 2008 I joined the Stanford AI Lab for a postdoc and co-founded Numovis Inc., a tech startup focused on motion tracking and computer vision for user interaction.
speakers.name: Christian Plagemann

speakers.bio: Zachary Gibson is a Senior Designer at Google working on cross product visual and interaction design with UXA.
speakers.name: Zachary Gibson

speakers.bio: Eric is a Staff Developer Programs Engineer on the Google Chrome team, working on Polymer and web components. He is the author of “Using the HTML5 Filesystem API” and the lead for html5rocks.com. Prior to Google, Eric worked as a software engineer at the University of Michigan where he designed rich web applications and APIs for the university’s 19 libraries.
speakers.name: Eric Bidelman

speakers.bio: Emerging UI at Google Research. Input & sensors, music & audio, and the web platform.
speakers.name: Boris Smus

speakers.bio: Android Wear Software Engineer. I enjoy bringing Android to new form factors so developers can build apps that are ubiquitous and useful.
speakers.name: Justin Koh

speakers.bio: Rebecca Moore is an Engineering Manager at Google, where she initiated and leads the development of Google Earth Engine, a new technology platform that puts an unprecedented amount of satellite imagery online for the first time and enables scientists to conduct global-scale monitoring and measurement of changes in the earth’s environment.  Rebecca also conceived and leads the Google Earth Outreach program, which supports nonprofits, communities and indigenous peoples around the world in applying Google's mapping tools to the world's pressing problems in areas such as environmental conservation, human rights and cultural preservation. Rebecca received a bachelor’s degree with honors from Brown University in Artificial Intelligence and a master’s degree from Stanford University. In 2013, Rebecca was recognized by the White House as a Champion of Change for Open Science.  Her personal work using Google Earth was instrumental in stopping the logging of more than a thousand acres of redwoods in her Santa Cruz Mountain community.
speakers.name: Rebecca Moore

speakers.bio: In 2011 Felipe Hoffa move from Chile to San Francisco to join Google as a Software Engineer. Since 2013 he's been a Developer Advocate on big data - to inspire developers around the world to leverage the Google Cloud Platform tools to analyze and understand their data in ways they could never before. You can find him in several YouTube videos, blog posts, and conferences around the world.
speakers.name: Felipe Hoffa

speakers.bio:
Brian Carlstrom is a member of the Android Runtime Team (ART).  Prior
to joining Google, Brian was at Stanford University where his research
focused on programming language design and implementation for hardware
transactional memory. Previously, Brian was on the first engineering
team at e-procurement startup Ariba where he was later product and
platform architect. Earlier Brian was a software engineer at ecommerce
startup Open Market and mobile device startup General Magic. Brian
holds a PhD and MS in computer science from Stanford University and an
MEng and SB in electrical engineering and computer science from the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
speakers.name: Brian  Carlstrom

speakers.bio: Lajos is the tech lead on the Android video framework team.  Combining his love of gadgets, music, multimedia and people, he is passionate about enabling developers to create spectacular multimedia experiences on the Android platform.
speakers.name: Lajos Molnar

speakers.bio: Ekaterina Volkova is a Software Engineer working on Google Cloud Platform. She leads container integration for the App Engine SDK.
speakers.name: Kate  Volkova

speakers.bio: Xavier Ducrohet is the Lead for the Android Developer Tools.
speakers.name: Xavier Ducrohet

speakers.bio: Jason Douglas is Group Product Manager for the Knowledge Graph platform.  He has also been involved with schema.org since its inception and has been working on the problems of information aggregation and syndication for nearly 20 years -- including at PointCast, Grand Central Networks, My Yahoo!, and Freebase (Metaweb), which was acquired by Google in 2010.
speakers.name: Jason Douglas

speakers.bio: Paul is a Developer Advocate who specializes in performance, UX and design. He has a personal mission to help make the web frictionless and blazing fast.
speakers.name: Paul Lewis

speakers.bio: Chris Ramsdale is a product manager for the Google Cloud Platform where he is focused on managed compute and data services.  Chris’ mission is to use the benefits of cloud computing to drive developer productivity and happiness.  Prior to joining Google, Chris worked extensively in the mobile space, starting as a Software Engineer at Motorola in 1997, and then joining local start ups as a Tech Lead and Product Manager building developers tools and platforms.
speakers.name: Chris Ramsdale

speakers.bio: Nazmul is an developer & designer focused on creating awesome user experiences powered by Android & Cloud developer technologies. He is passionate about UX engineering, the design process, mobile computing, cloud computing, startups, and innovation. He created the UXD for Developers show on the Android Developers Channel on YouTube, started the UXD for Developers G+ community.
speakers.name: Nazmul Idris

speakers.bio: Ari is a senior designer and manager on the Android Design team, contributing to cross-functional efforts within Android and across Google. Prior to joining Google, he worked in a wide range of areas including projection design for theater, film title design and motion graphics, and visual effects for film and special venues.
speakers.name: Ari Sachter-Zeltzer

speakers.bio: Lawrence has been working at Google for more than six years on mobile, Android, and Search.  He has more than fifteen years of experience in the mobile and wireless industries, holding a variety of product management, engineering, and marketing roles at both startups and established companies.  Lawrence has a Masters degree in Business Administration from the University of California at Berkeley Haas School of Business, and Masters and Bachelors degrees in Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
speakers.name: Lawrence Chang

speakers.bio:
Jonah has been working as a professional user experience designer since 1999. He has been involved in all aspects of the design process, from leading teams through to individual contribution, with expertise in both creative and technical fields.

He is well versed with consumer product strategy, information architecture and interaction design, visual and motion design, user research, prototyping and front end programming, integrated design across multiple platforms, and marketing & client relations.

He is currently working as a Lead User Experience Designer for Google in California, most recently leading the design of the new Google Maps.
speakers.name: Jonah Jones

speakers.bio: Eyal Rabinovich manages the world-wide marketing and business development activities in PlayScape, a leading mobile game publisher. As an entrepreneur with extensive experience in developing and marketing consumer-facing products, he works with game developers to distribute and commercialize their games. Before founding PlayScape Eyal served as an officer in an elite IDF Navy unit, in addition to being a Senior Software Engineer at Hedge-Tech Financial Engineering, and Lipman Electronic Engineering Ltd.
speakers.name: Eyal Rabinovich

speakers.bio: Romain was until recently the tech lead on the Android 2D rendering pipeline and UI toolkit. He worked on Android from 1.0 to 4.4 and loves helping application developers optimize their applications.
speakers.name: Romain Guy

speakers.bio: Andy works in the Android platform media team, bringing more audio fun to your Android device.
speakers.name: Andy Hung

speakers.bio: Greg Hartrell is the lead product manager for Google Play Games: Google's game platform that helps developers reach and unite millions of players. In his spare time, he enjoys flying birds through plumbing structures, boss battles and pulling rare objects from mystery boxes.
speakers.name: Greg Hartrell

speakers.bio: Rachel is a Senior Designer on the Google Play team and leading imagery direction at Google.
speakers.name: Rachel Been

speakers.bio: Peter Norvig is a Director of Research at Google; previously he directed Google's core search algorithms group. He is co-author of Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach, the leading textbook in the field, and co-teacher of an Artificial Intelligence class that signed up 160,000 students, helping to kick off the current round of massive open online classes. He is a Fellow of AAAI, ACM, the California Academy of Science and the American Academy of Arts & Sciences.
speakers.name: Peter Norvig

speakers.bio: Jennifer is the Technical Lead Manager for the Google+ Platform. The Platform team helps users bring their Google experience with them across the internet, and the best of their internet experience back to Google.
speakers.name: Jennifer W. Lin

speakers.bio:
I am an engineer on the Android UI Toolkit team, working on graphics, animations, UI widgets, and performance. I eventually get around to recording DevBytes tutorials on these topics. In the meantime, you can also find me online co-hosting the new Android Developers Backstage podcast.
I've written programming and comedy books and enjoy giving presentations at developer events. Like this one.
speakers.name: Chet Haase

speakers.bio: Steve is a media streaming engineer working to annihilate buffering and deliver crystal-clear video for all YouTube playbacks.
speakers.name: Steven Robertson

speakers.bio: Eric is the founding CTO of One Degree, a nonprofit working to revolutionize the way low-income families access social services. Eric came to the organization to continue his work in applying technology to improve the lives of underserved people in need. Prior to joining, Eric was a product manager and engineer at Change.org, which powers social justice campaigns around the world. Previously, Eric consulted at M+R Strategic Services, working for nonprofits in the public interest, running online advocacy and fundraising efforts. Eric has a BA in Computer Science from Goucher College, and has been a software engineer elsewhere, building web and desktop applications for the social sector.
speakers.name: Eric Lukoff

speakers.bio: Ankur is a Developer Advocate experienced in building for Android, Maps and Google Cast. He enjoys supporting developers in building innovative, scalable and performant apps. Ankur is also the Mobile Technical Lead for Google Santa Tracker where he loves spreading holiday cheer.
speakers.name: Ankur Kotwal

speakers.bio: Will is an engineer in Google Play who splits his time between Play Newsstand, core UX frameworks, and product prototyping.
speakers.name: Will  Kiefer

speakers.bio: Christian Robertson leads the visual design effort for Android. He is also the designer of the Roboto type family.
speakers.name: Christian Robertson

speakers.bio:
John is a designer and writer who’s worked on consumer, enterprise, and medical software products. As part of the team who redesigned YouTube in 2011, John led design for YouTube Channels. He also helped create FeedBurner, which Google acquired in 2007. 

As a design partner at Google Ventures, John helps startups use design successfully. He’s worked with more than 50 companies, including Pocket, Blue Bottle Coffee, RetailMeNot, and Foundation Medicine. John is also GV’s in-house copywriter and content editor.
speakers.name: John Zeratsky

speakers.bio: Manfred is an Associate Product Manager on the Cloud Platform team, working on enabling great Cloud+Android interactions, and making developers' lives easier with Google Cloud SDK. Manfred holds Computer Science degrees from Cambridge and Oxford, and prior to joining Google worked on productivity software at Microsoft.
speakers.name: Manfred Zabarauskas

speakers.bio:
Mark McBride is services engineer lead at Nest Labs, creator of the Nest Learning Thermostat and Nest Protect: Smoke + Carbon Monoxide Alarm. Mark is responsible for the development of Nest’s server infrastructure, which makes it possible for Nest customers to connect with their homes from wherever they are.
 
Prior to Nest, Mark was an early developer on Twitter's streaming API, delivering thousands of messages per second in real time to millions of users. He also managed developer productivity and led the web delivery, developer tools and infrastructure test teams during his time at Twitter. Mark also held engineering management positions at both EMC and Luminate. He earned his MBA degree from the University of California, Berkeley, and his BS degrees in electrical engineering and computer science from the University of California, Davis.
speakers.name: Mark McBride

speakers.bio: Jatin is an Android framework developer who is passionate about enabling seamless transition of users between devices. Over last few years working on Android he has gained wide experience ranging from authentication, security, cloud messaging and cloud storage. He as worked at Google for last 6 years and in his past life has worked on building scalable backends for Google Search Quality human rating platform.
speakers.name: Jatin Lodhia

speakers.bio: Stephanie Hannon is a Director of Product Management for Social Impact at Google, focused on building innovative technology help people broaden engagement with their community, government and nonprofits. Focus areas range from changing how the world prepares and responds to natural disasters to using data to help cities make evidenced based decisions. She recently transitioned from Facebook where she led product management for Site Integrity and Trust Engineering, working to ensure Facebook is a safe space for communication where people use their authentic identities. Prior to Facebook, Stephanie co-founded an ambitious startup that aimed to bring web innovations, technology and transparency to residential energy management and markets. Stephanie spent seven years as a product manager at Google, most recently as the product lead for Google Wave based in Google's Sydney office. Prior to Sydney she worked in Google's Zurich office, leading the product team for Google Maps for Europe, Middle East and Africa, and before this she was a product manager for Gmail at Google in Mountain View. Stephanie also spent six years as a software engineer building operating systems for the Catalyst line of switches at Cisco Systems after the acquisition of a startup she joined called Granite Systems. Stephanie holds a B.S. Computer Systems Engineering and M.S.E.E. from Stanford University and an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School. Stephanie loves traveling (71 countries and counting) and diving with sharks.
speakers.name: Steph Hannon

speakers.bio: William Vambenepe leads the Product Management team for Big Data on Google Cloud Platform.
speakers.name: William Vambenepe

speakers.bio: Marwa Mabrouk is a Product Manager at Google. Marwa focuses on bringing Google’s capabilities in Cloud Computing and Big Data to Google Cloud Platform users. Before joining Google, Marwa has dedicated her time and attention to furthering new frontiers for spatial analysis. She led the development of the first hosted web services in the industry to offer maps online, as well as leading the development of the first managed services for spatial analysis in the cloud. She has been a strong evangelist of Cloud Computing and Big Data during the last few years, and continues to work towards wider usability of Big Data technologies in the Cloud.
speakers.name: Marwa Mabrouk

speakers.bio: Jordan Tigani has more than 15 years of professional software development experience, the last 4 of which have been spent building BigQuery. Prior to joining Google, Jordan worked at a number of star-crossed startups, where he learned to make data-based predictions. He is a co-author of Google BigQuery Analytics, and plays soccer for several recreational teams in Seattle.
speakers.name: Jordan Tigani

speakers.bio: Ellie Powers is a product manager at Google Play, focused on developing the apps ecosystem. She joined Google to re-launch the Google Play Developer Console, and is now working to make Play the best place for developers and users alike.
speakers.name: Ellie Powers

speakers.bio: Jamal Eason is the Product Manager for Android Studio & Android SDK Tools. He enjoys helping developers make awesome apps.
speakers.name: Jamal Eason

speakers.bio: Brahim is a Product Manager at Google Play responsible for commerce, search, and discovery.  Brahim works on features such as the Google Play purchase experience and integration of new forms of payment such as PayPal.  Brahim holds an MBA from the Stanford Graduate School of Business and a BS in Computer Science and Engineering from UCLA. Brahim has also worked at Amazon and Deloitte in addition to starting a company in the past.
speakers.name: Brahim Elbouchikhi

speakers.bio: Bob leads games business development for Google Play. He focuses on growing Google Play game developer revenue, managing new initiative outreach, and influencing product development of key features including payments and discovery/ distribution.
speakers.name: Bob Meese

speakers.bio: As a webmaster trends analyst, Pierre follows industry trends in SEO and web development in order to help different Google teams build better tools for webmasters and improve search quality. Pierre also writes for the Webmaster Central Blog and participates in Google and external forums, helping site owners troubleshoot search-related problems and get the most out of Google Webmaster Tools.
speakers.name: Pierre Far

speakers.bio: Justin Uberti is one of the co-creators of the WebRTC project, and leads the WebRTC engineering team at Google. Previously, Justin helped create Google+ Hangouts.
speakers.name: Justin Uberti

speakers.bio:
Stefan is a founding member of the Technology Advisory Board for Beyond 12, a nonprofit created 
to increase the number of traditionally underserved students who earn a college degree. Among other things, Stefan is supporting the development of Beyond 12’s mobile app, MyCoach, which helps low-income students navigate the path to college and stay on track once they arrive, significantly enhancing graduation rates. He is currently a director at Slalom Digital, focusing on creating digital experiences for Fortune 500 companies. Stefan has been leading teams that build software for close to 15 years across various industries. Prior to Slalom, Stefan helped bring solutions to life with teams at Dell and helped launch several companies, including Explorica, an innovator and leader in the group travel industry, as well as Just-In-Time, an early innovator in the team collaboration and communications space.
speakers.name: Stefan Nilsson

speakers.bio: Eric manages Google's elections and civic engagement products and programs. For the 2012 US elections, his team developed and launched online polling place and ballot information tools that were used over 23 Million times. Eric has also managed the launch of similar services for over 25 elections worldwide, including in India, Kenya, Mexico, Egypt, Germany, and Australia. Eric's team recently launched the Google Civic Information API to make it easier for developers to build useful new civic apps.
speakers.name: Eric Hysen

speakers.bio: Brady Forrest is VP of PCH International’s incubator, Highway1. Previously chair for O’Reilly’s Where 2.0 and Web 2.0 Expo in San Francisco and NYC, Brady continues to write for O’Reilly Radar. He started Ignite, a geek event that has spread to over a hundred cities worldwide. Brady lives in San Francisco, where he builds robots and cars for Burning Man and competes for Mayor of finer establishments. You can track his web travels at Truffle Honey or @brady. Recently, he has started blogging about Burning Man & desert fashion.
speakers.name: Brady Forrest

speakers.bio: Dan is a product guy who loves working on things that make ops easier.  Prior to Google, Dan was one of the founders of Stackdriver, a provider of "intelligent" monitoring services for cloud-powered applications.
speakers.name: Daniel Belcher

speakers.bio: Ilya Grigorik is a web performance engineer and developer advocate at Google, where his focus is on making the web fast and driving adoption of performance best practices.
speakers.name: Ilya Grigorik

speakers.bio: Sriram's the Product Manager for Chrome Apps. He's excited about building a platform for web developers that combines the best of web and native. Before he joined the Chrome team, he was with the Google Cloud team building a framework for mobile backends.
speakers.name: Sriram Saroop

speakers.bio: Amy Wu  is a Product Manager focused on creating a great Google Play storefront. Prior to Google Play she spent years on search and advertising at Google.
speakers.name: Amy Wu

speakers.bio: Tor Norbye is the tech lead for visual editors in Android Studio, and also spends a lot of time working on lint static analysis.
speakers.name: Tor Norbye

speakers.bio: Hannah Cho is a visual designer for Android UX team.  She finds delight in bringing print-like design language into Android and believes that visual design can further impact and improve the Android user experience.
speakers.name: Hannah Cho

speakers.bio:
Matt Rogers is founder and VP of Engineering at Nest Labs, creator of the Nest Learning Thermostat and Nest Protect: Smoke + Carbon Monoxide Alarm. By applying modern design and technology, Nest aims to revitalize these stagnant - yet very important - industries. Matt is responsible for all product development at Nest, ranging from mechanical design to software to web services, and everything in between. Matt also serves on Nest's board of directors.       

Prior to Nest, Matt was responsible for iPod software development at Apple, from concept to production. He was one of the first engineers on the original iPhone, and involved in the development of 10 generations of iPod, 5 generations of iPhone, and the first iPad. He earned his BS and MS degrees from Carnegie Mellon University.
speakers.name: Matt Rogers

speakers.bio: Mamie is a Program Manager in Developer Relations who designs experiences, communities and environments for grassroots innovation. She first joined Google in May 2006 after receiving her B.A. in Urban Studies from Stanford University. While on the Google Labs team, she co-created The Garage, Google's hacker, maker, design space. Shifting her focus from Google's internal Engineering culture, she now supports the global community of developers, designers and entrepreneurs who are building meaningful and magical experiences for Google Glass.
speakers.name: Mamie Rheingold

speakers.bio: Glenn is a software engineer in the Android media team, with a focus on low-level audio and performance. His background includes real-time operating systems and embedded applications, and he enjoys playing piano.
speakers.name: Glenn Kasten

speakers.bio: Tomas Isdal has been a Software Engineer with Google Cloud Platform since 2012. He is currently the Tech Lead for Managed VMs. Prior to joining Google, Tomas was the founder at a small startup where he experienced Google Cloud from a customer perspective. Tomas has a PhD from the University of Washington, his dissertation focused on privacy and performance of p2p and distributed systems.
speakers.name: Tomas Isdal

speakers.bio: Austin is a Product Manager for Android Wear.  He joined the team in 2013 and is passionate about delivering amazing experiences to users through wearable technology.
speakers.name: Austin Robison

speakers.bio: Hayes Raffle leads the interaction research team conducting advanced development for Google Glass. He holds a Ph.D. and M.S. in Media Arts and Sciences from the MIT Media Lab, and a B.A. in fine art from Yale. Hayes specializes in creating interactive toys, systems and devices that engage people's touch to improve communication, education, and creative expression.
speakers.name: Hayes Raffle

speakers.bio: Jenny Gove is a User Experience Researcher at Google, where she conducts research on smartphone and tablet use. Previously Jenny managed the Apps, Social, and the Ads Design Research teams at Google, conducted research at Sun Microsystems, and created interaction designs at a start­up, Zadu. Jenny started her career in academia, and was a Lecturer at the Open University, UK, where she conducted Educational Technology research. She received her Ph.D. from the University of Southampton in the UK.
speakers.name: Jennifer Gove

speakers.bio: Adam is a software engineer on the Android framework team.
speakers.name: Adam Powell

speakers.bio:
Jake is a design partner at Google Ventures. He created Google Ventures’ design sprint process, and has run over 80 sprints with startups like About.me, Nest, AngelList, and Foundation Medicine. He's spoken about design process at Stanford, UC-Berkeley, and Columbia University.

Previously, Jake was a design vigilante at Google, leading sprints for everything from Gmail to Google X to Chrome. Jake also started a 20% project that became Google Hangouts.

Long ago, Jake grew up on a rural island in Washington State. He is currently among the world’s tallest designers.
speakers.name: Jake Knapp

speakers.bio: Yoky Matsuoka is Vice President of Technology at Nest, where she leads the development of the learning and control technology for the Nest thermostat and smoke detector. Previously, Yoky served as the Head of Innovation at Google and Professor of Computer Science and Engineering at the University of Washington. She graduated from UC Berkeley and earned an MS and PhD in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from MIT. She has also received the MacArthur Genius Award for her work in robotics and neuroscience.
speakers.name: Yoky Matsuoka

speakers.bio:
Alex is a Software Engineer working in the Chrome and Blink teams. In the past several years he has contributed to the creation of Web Components, Service Workers, and Google Chrome Frame.

Alex serves as a member of the W3C's Technical Architecture Group which reviews and shapes the design of new web platform features to ensure that they are coherent and create an integrated, layered whole. He is one of the authors of the Extensible Web Manifesto: http://extensiblewebmanifesto.org/. Alex also serves on ECMA TC39, the standards committee for JavaScript where he has helped champion the addition of features like Promises and Classes for the next version of the language (ES6).

Prior to joining Google, Alex worked on large-scale JavaScript frameworks and the sorts of rich client-side apps that require them.
speakers.name: Alex Russell

speakers.bio: Weston is a Product Manager on Google Cloud Platform. He has spent the last 8 years working in developer tools, with a passion for creating great user experiences to help developers get started faster. Today, he spends much of his time creating and improving the on-boarding experiences for the Google Cloud Platform.
speakers.name: Weston  Hutchins

speakers.bio: Lara Swanson is the Engineering Manager of Performance at Etsy. She champions page load time, experiment-driven design, and delivering a consistent experience to screens of all sizes.
speakers.name: Lara Swanson

speakers.bio: John is the Engineering Manager for the Google Cast SDK and Cast services teams. At Google, he also managed the Google Play store team. Prior to Google, John was at Microsoft, working, among other things on IPTV services and TV apps. In his copious spare time, he is an avid gamer, comic book reader and family man.
speakers.name: John Affaki

speakers.bio: Reuven Lax has spent the past seven years helping to shape Google's data processing and analysis strategy. For much of that time he has focused on Google's low-latency, streaming data processing effort, and he's very excited to bring Google's data-processing experience to the world at large. In 2013 he was proud to publish a paper on this effort which can be found at http://http://research.google.com/pubs/pub41378.html. When not at work, Reuven enjoys swing dancing, rock climbing, and exploring new parts of the world.
speakers.name: Reuven Lax

speakers.bio:
Susan is the CEO of Hack the Hood -- a nonprofit addressing digital equity by training low-income 
kids to build websites for local small businesses, actively supporting them to launch their own tech 
careers. She also co-founded Oakland Local, a news hub for Oakland and Live Work Oakland, a 
tech & business innovation news site. In her corporate life, she was VP of Network Development at 
Netscape and America Online, and Senior Director of Product and Revenue Optimization at Yahoo! 
She was the founder of a TechStars incubator company and launched Code for Oakland, a 
tech event focused on building apps to serve the Oakland community.
speakers.name: Susan Mernit

speakers.bio: Complexity geek. Evangelist for the power of open…hardware should be more like software. Architect of factory of the future. Drone designer & rocket scientist. MIT. Caltech. Georgetown. Head of Google's Project Ara. Occasional pilot (yes, be very afraid).
speakers.name: Paul Eremenko

speakers.bio: Based in London, UK, Mandy is a Developer Advocate at Google specializing in Cloud technologies. One of her main aims in life is to make the world a better place for developers building applications for the Cloud. In the past year she has presented at over 30 events, including two Cloud Developer Platform Roadshow tours and large developer events such as JFokus, PHP UK and Velocity. In her spare time Mandy is learning Japanese and likes to play the guitar.
speakers.name: Mandy Waite

speakers.bio: Daniel ran an agency in Canada, was creative dir at Digg, and founded a company called Milk that was acquired by Google. He now works with Google Ventures' many portfolio companies on their design challenges.
speakers.name: Daniel Burka

speakers.bio: Devon has spent the last three years working on the Dart language, and more recently bootstrapping a Dart development environment written in Dart. His background includes language tooling and user interface design.
speakers.name: Devon Carew

speakers.bio: Michael is the tech lead on the Google team working on mobile payments. He is also a co-author of the book "Android in Practice."
speakers.name: Michael Galpin

speakers.bio: Timothy is a Staff Developer Advocate at Google working on the Glass platform where he's helped launch the Google Mirror API and the Glass Development Kit.  He previously worked on Google+ where he helped launch multiple plugins and APIs including the +1 button.  He has taught broadcasting, theater, engineering, and various forms of new media at the University of California at Santa Cruz, the Academy of Art University, and the Digital Media Academy.  He has a B.S. in Computer Engineering, a Theater Arts graduate degree, and an M.F.A. in Digital Arts and New Media from U.C. Santa Cruz.  He loves solving problems and believes in improving life through science and art.
speakers.name: Timothy Jordan

speakers.bio: Richard is an interaction designer and manager on the Android Design team, leading UI efforts spanning both platform and apps. Prior to joining Google, he designed consumer experiences for TiVo, Sirius, Dell, and AOL.
speakers.name: Rich Fulcher

speakers.bio:
Jonathan Alferness is currently a Director of Product Management and Global Head of Mobile Ads Products for Google where he oversees product strategy and development for the search, display and app monetization.  Before this he was Director of Search Ads where he focused on Ads Quality, AdSense for Search, Personalization, Optimization and Bidding.  

Jonathan is a 15+ year veteran of the online industry where he has focused on building next generation web technologies, and worked closely with numerous Fortune 500 companies to understand how to embrace the migration to online, and now to mobile.  Jonathan holds a BS degree in Computer Science from Cornell and spent time doing graduate work at Caltech.  He lives in San Francisco, with his wife and two young children.
speakers.name: Jonathan Alferness

speakers.bio: Melody Meckfessel is an Engineering Director leading the team responsible for developer tooling and infrastructure for our Cloud Platform.  We build highly scalable systems from IDEs to build systems to highly automated test systems to devops tools and finally release and deployment to Google's Cloud.
speakers.name: Melody Meckfessel

speakers.bio: Toby is an engineering manager working on Google's cloud platform, with a focus on using logging, monitoring and alerting to make developers on the Google cloud products happier and more productive. Prior to his current cloud efforts, Toby worked on Google's internal infrastructure, and was a distributed systems engineer at NetApp, Laurel Networks and FORE Systems.
speakers.name: Toby Smith

speakers.bio: Viktor is a Senior Designer at Google working on cross product visual and interaction design with UXA. Previously Viktor led the visual re-design of Google Maps.
speakers.name: Viktor Persson

speakers.bio: Majd runs the engineering team in charge of Cast and Chromecast. Majd joined Google in 2011 and was focused on solving the 10' interaction model for large screens. Prior to joining Google Majd was the lead architect for Microsoft Mediaroom.
speakers.name: Majd Bakar

speakers.bio:
Julia Wilkowski designs learning experiences on Google's engineering education team. Since 2012 she has worked on the instructional, community and research elements of massive open online courses like Power Searching and Mapping with Google. Previously at Google, her projects included revamping new hire orientation, manager training, and training sales teams in Asia and Latin America. 

Prior to joining Google in 2007, Julia trained astronauts at NASA, worked as an instructional designer at Informatica, and taught science to sixth graders. She received an M.A. in Education with a focus on Instructional Technology from San Jose State University and a B.S. in Neuroscience from Brown University.
speakers.name: Julia Wilkowski

speakers.bio: Kevin Moore is a Product Manager for the Dart language, libraries and tools. Before joining Google, Kevin was a software consultant specializing in Javascript, Ruby, and C#. He has been involved with the Dart project – writing, speaking, and contributing – for over two years.
speakers.name: Kevin Moore

speakers.bio: Bethany Fong is a user experience designer for Android and a member of a cross-functional team that shapes design across Google. She's contributed to Android system design, Android@Home, and Accessibility. Bethany studied Product Design and Engineering at Stanford University.
speakers.name: Bethany Fong

speakers.bio: Jon has been at Google since 2006, where he currently serves as Principal Designer for Google Search and Maps. Jon was the first designer for Google Autocomplete, was the instigator for Google Instant, and led the Search UX team through three redesigns and the addition of new features such as the Knowledge Graph and voice search. In his current role Jon works to define, develop, and direct a vision of where Google Search and Maps should go in order to deliver a simple, useful, and beautiful experience.
speakers.name: Jon Wiley

speakers.bio: Rachad leads Android Media framework, the group responsible for building Android’s Audio, Video, DRM and Camera infrastructure. He was formerly Chief Technology Officer at Bluestreak Technology where he led the the development of HTML5 and Flash video technologies for embedded platforms. He contributed to the development of the very first Digital TV middlewares (OpenTV) and PVR platforms (TiVo).
speakers.name: Rachad Alao

speakers.bio: Chris was the technical lead for Google Santa Tracker, a delightful project built by a group of merry volunteers. When not tracking Saint Nick, he is a senior engineer on the Google Developer Relations team, focusing primarily on the Google Maps APIs (mobile and web). You'll often find Chris cruising around on a longboard near Google's offices in Pyrmont, Sydney.
speakers.name: Chris Broadfoot

speakers.bio: The passion for design has led Gus to experience different aspects of the design process. From Online Advertising in Germany; to Broadcast Design in Italy; to Interactive Video Production in Brazil. Joined Google UK in 2012 and is currently working with the Android team in Mountain View, juggling between wearable computing efforts and a newborn baby!
speakers.name: Gustavo Sonoda

speakers.bio:
Koh is currently a Business Development Manager for Google Play Games where she leads indie game and influencer outreach and international market strategy. As a hardcore gamer, she works with indie game developers to create best user experiences, building player communities, and launching sustainable businesses on Google Play. She also advises game companies on international expansion and recently spent last year starting the Play business development team in Korea.

Prior to Google, Koh was a strategy consultant at the Cambridge Group, where she helped clients develop and execute growth strategies driven by identifying unmet consumer demand and creating differentiated products and services. She holds a BA in Economics from the University of Chicago. In her free time, she enjoys playing and watching sports ranging from tennis to yoga.
speakers.name: Koh Kim

speakers.bio: Matías Duarte leads the Android Design team. He’s responsible for all aspects of the software and visual experience across the Android platform, core applications services, and the design of Nexus tablets and phones.
speakers.name: Matias Duarte

speakers.bio: Paul Bakaus is a Developer Advocate at Google. Prior to joining Google, he created the popular UI framework jQuery UI and later inspired the web community with the Aves Engine, the world's first plugin-less game engine for the web that was later acquired by Zynga. His current mission is to enable every web developer to build rich, immersive and user friendly experiences for the entire screen continuum of devices.
speakers.name: Paul Bakaus

speakers.bio: Ian is a member of the Android Runtime and Tools group. He holds a PhD, M.Phil and B.Sc from the University of Manchester. He is a fellow of the British Computer Society and ACM SIGPLAN award winner. Ian is an expert in the areas of managed runtimes, concurrent garbage collectors, compilers and binary translators.
speakers.name: Ian Rogers

speakers.bio: With over 15 years in design and innovation, Ratna’s experience encompasses design thinking, user experience, strategy and visioning for consumer products and services in emerging markets for digital, physical and human touchpoints. She has worked in various industries ranging from healthcare, telecom, entertainment, finance and retail to elearning, search and social media to build seamlessly integrated ecosystems across mobile, tablet, desktop and television. Prior to joining Google, Ratna was a Creative Direcor at frog design. Her past work includes engagements with Nike, Disney, Skype, Qualcomm, Sony, PayPal, Chase, AT&T and Gap Inc. With a focus on experience design, branding and product strategy, Ratna’s holistic approach places the user at the center and underscores the importance of storytelling and the context of the culture at large. Not only should design question and offer meaning, but it should always strive to enhance an experience and make it delightful. It's what leads to lasting impressions, preferences, and performance. Ultimately, great design provides a mindset to transform organizations, helping them to reinvent themselves and their products in masterful ways.
speakers.name: Ratna Desai

speakers.bio: David M. Hogue, Ph.D. is a UX Designer, Manager of the Google Travel UX team, and an Applied Psychologist with more than 15 years experience. He combines his UX design, research, and psychology skills to bring deeper insight into user behavior, uncover strategic opportunities for innovation, and to solve challenging UX problems. Dave also teaches UX and interaction design courses at SFSU and applied psychology in the graduate program at GGU.
speakers.name: Dave Hogue

speakers.bio: Jaime Waydo works at Google[x] as a Systems Engineer on the self-driving car program. Before joining Google she was the Director of Engineering at Translucent Medical, where she helped transform the way physicians "see" inside patients during surgery.  Much of her earlier career was spent at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, CA, where highlights included leading the rover mobility mechanical team for the Mars Science Laboratory mission. Jaime earned her Bachelor's degree in Mechanical Engineering from Montana State University in 2000. She also completed her Master's degree in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at UCLA in 2006.
speakers.name: Jaime Waydo

speakers.bio: Megan is an entrepreneur, tech evangelist, engineer, catalyst and connector. At Google [x], Megan works on a range of projects including co-creating/hosting Solve For X to encourage and amplify technology-based moonshot thinking and collaboration. For nine years prior she led Google’s New Business Development team managing early-stage partnerships, pilot explorations, and technology licensing for Google’s global engineering and product teams. She led the acquisitions of Keyhole (Google Earth), Where2Tech (Google Maps) and Picasa, and also led the Google.org team transition to add more engineering with Google Crisis Response, Google for Nonprofits, and Earth Outreach. Prior to joining Google, Megan was CEO and earlier, COO of PlanetOut, the leading LGBT online community. Over the years, Megan has contributed to a wide range of engineering projects, including an award-winning bicycle lock, space station construction program, and solar cookstoves. She holds a bachelor's and master's degrees in mechanical engineering from MIT, where she now serves on the board. She completed her master's thesis work at the MIT Media Lab.
speakers.name: Megan Smith

speakers.bio:
Marco is the Design Lead for for Google Play and core Android apps. He advocates for Android applications to be beautifully designed and express their brand univoquely and he runs the Beautiful Apps collection on the Play Store.
Prior to Google he worked on a wide range of industries, designing experiences for Nokia, LG Electronics, Siemens VDO and JWT.
speakers.name: Marco Paglia

speakers.bio: Interface technology guru. Core-contributor to Kinetic. Wiimotes TED talker. YouTube watch = 15M. Technology Review TR35. Carnegie Mellon PhD.  Now, Project Tango Lead trying to make the future awesome.
speakers.name: Johnny Lee

speakers.bio:
Visual Designer at Google Play. Teddy design involve a large part of the Play visual design like the Store, Music and the Play brand system.
He used to work for Nokia, Squarespace and SumAll. Music addicted, comics reader, gamer and a fan photographer.
speakers.name: Taddeo Zacchini

speakers.bio: Hélène is a UX Motion Designer for a product design group at Google.
speakers.name: Hélène Park

speakers.bio: Jonathan Lee is design lead and founding member of Google UXA, a cross-functional group focused on developing a unified design framework across Google’s products and platforms. Prior to Google he was an Art Director at 2x4. Jonathan graduated from Pratt Institute in 2005 with a BFA in Communication Design.
speakers.name: Jonathan Lee

speakers.bio: Alley leads the User Experience team for Google Shopping, whose mission is to balance feature sets and business goals with a magical user experience and encourage solutions that represent the most user-centric intersection of content, business, technology, and design.
speakers.name: Alley Rutzel

speakers.bio: Designer on the Android Wear team. I've been designing and building wearable computing prototypes for several years, and previously worked on Google's search products. Originally from Ireland, now living with my wife and son in San Francisco.
speakers.name: Emmet Connolly

speakers.bio:
Eddy is the tech lead for Android's camera framework team, which is responsible for Android's camera API and camera hardware abstraction layer.
Prior to working at Android, he completed a doctorate in electrical engineering at Stanford University, focusing on programmable digital cameras and computational photography.
speakers.name: Eddy Talvala

speakers.bio: As a Developer Advocate, Dan Galpin has spent the last four years at Google working with the Play and Android teams around gaming technologies and directly with developers as they bring their vision of gaming to Android.
speakers.name: Dan Galpin

speakers.bio:
Since 1998, I have been called a consultant, contractor, web developer, CEO, CTO, cofounder, software engineer, presenter, author and occasionally other names that an unusual burst of good taste prevents me from mentioning here.

In all of these roles I have endeavored to cultivate technical mastery, integrity, humility and a sense of humor while continuing to be straightforward and plainspoken. I am, after all, the grandson of a West Virginia coal miner.

These days, I lead the amazing engineers on the HTML5 TV team at YouTube. We are using web technologies to develop rich, interactive experiences on a huge variety of different hardware platforms for millions of YouTube viewers.

While I was originally raised by alligators in the Gulf Coast swamps of St. Petersburg, Florida, I have lived all over the San Francisco Bay Area since 1997. 

These days I make my home near the southernmost edge of San Francisco in the never-ending winter of Bernal Heights.
speakers.name: Luke Bayes

speakers.bio: Braden Kowitz is a product designer, prototyper, and storyteller. He's also a Design Partner at Google Ventures and founded the team's Design Studio. He advises startups on UX Design and Product Development. Before joining Google Ventures, Braden led design for several Google Products, including Gmail, Google Buzz, Google Apps for Business, Google Spreadsheets, OpenSocial, and Google Trends.
speakers.name: Braden Kowitz

speakers.bio: Annette has been with Google since 2012, where she currently works as a Sr. Designer on Google Maps. She brings projects from development through to completion, defines user interface for new and existing products and features, develops high level mockups, motion graphics and prototypes, to effectively communicate interaction and visual design ideas. She has experience integrating design across multiple platforms, from desktop, mobile, TV, and gaming consoles.
speakers.name: Annette Leong

speakers.bio: Aaron Harris was cofounder of Tutorspree, which was funded by Y Combinator in 2011. Before Tutorspree he worked at Bridgewater Associates, where he managed product and operations for an analytics group. He has an AB in History and Literature from Harvard.
speakers.name: Aaron Harris

speakers.bio: Been working on the Android cloud team for a little over one year. Started out on the provisioning team - OTAs, release cycle, all that fun stuff. Eventually took over the SyncManager framework, and now I'm focusing entirely on client side - both in Google Play Services and the platform, with an emphasis on network usage.
speakers.name: Matthew Williams

speakers.bio: Olly is a member of the Android team. He's played a part developing both YouTube and Play Movies for Android, leads development of ExoPlayer, and has a keen interest in improving video playback across the whole Android ecosystem. Prior to joining Google, Olly completed a Ph.D. at the University of Cambridge.
speakers.name: Oliver Woodman

speakers.bio: Francesco Nerieri leads the global Mobile Cloud engineering team at Google. The team develops innovative solutions for the mobile messaging, synchronization, storage, provisioning, authentication and identity technologies.  With over 10 years of experience in the wireless communications and distributed systems fields, Francesco applies his expertise to direct the team's initiatives to advance mobile cloud technologies.
speakers.name: Francesco Nerieri

speakers.bio: Jake works in Google Chrome's developer relations team, working on specs, implementations, and ensuring developers have tools to make their jobs less painful. He's a big fan of offline-first, time-to-render optimisations, progressive enhancement, and all of that responsive stuff. He's one of the designers of the ServiceWorker API.
speakers.name: Jake Archibald

speakers.bio:
Prakash Hariramani is a senior product manager in the Google Wallet team. His mission is to make the mobile commerce and checkout process fast and easy for developers and merchants selling physical goods & services through Google Wallet Instant Buy.
Prakash started his career in financial services and then moved to mobile and then decided to combine the two. Prakash has a Bachelor's degree from Franklin & Marshall College and a Master of Science from Carnegie Mellon University
speakers.name: Prakash Hariramani

speakers.bio: Rob Dodson is a developer advocate at Google where he focuses on Polymer and Web Components. In previous roles he’s helped craft design systems for massive enterprise companies,  user interfaces for console titles, and even built the occasional enchanted princess game. These days his mission is to fight for a better web and to help developers build great experiences.
speakers.name: Rob Dodson

speakers.bio: As a senior interaction designer on the Android team, Dave has contributed to Android Gmail, Android Email, Android System design and cross-product design efforts across Google. Previously, Dave worked at frog design where he developed product and service ecosystems for a variety of clients. Dave holds a Masters in Interaction Design from Interaction Ivrea.
speakers.name: Dave Chiu

speakers.bio: Nicholas is a design generalist at Google, leading a group that drives cross-platform visual and user experience design. In his time at Google, he has contributed to both web and mobile initiatives through Google Chrome, Chrome OS, Google Search App, Voice Search and more.
speakers.name: Nicholas Jitkoff

speakers.bio: Puneet is the program lead for Solve for X (www.solveforx.com) - an open moonshot platform powered by Google [x].  She discovers and attracts individuals and organizations working on tech moonshots and uses the convening power of Google to accelerate their progress.  Before joining Google she was an Analyst at Goldman Sachs, focused on picking structurally-advantaged companies that have the potential to disrupt their industries over the coming two decades.  She served on the Board of Directors for Colin Powell's non-profit - America's Promise, co-founded an NGO called Freedom's Answer, and co-authored a book under the same title.  Puneet received her BSc and MA from Oxford University.
speakers.name: Puneet Ahira

blocks.title: After hours
blocks.subtitle: Enjoy craft brews in our beer garden, San Francisco's illustrious food trucks, and local indie bands.

sessions.description: Google I/O's much-anticipated kickoff event will make you among the first developers to see what we've been working on here at Google. If you're not joining us at Moscone, grab some popcorn, kick back and enjoy the show directly from your Android powered device.
sessions.title: Keynote

sessions.description: SourceGraph is a code search and analytics engine that indexes the world of open source code. In this session we'll see how a small team used Go to build the service.
sessions.title: Sourcegraph: A code search engine in Go

sessions.description: Build the best version of your app. Come learn tips and tricks for building truly great Android apps - get the most out of Android Studio’s design tools, master the intricacies of Gradle, tune your client performance with procstats and systrace, simplify your backend with Google Play services, and more. Android experts will be on hand to tear down your app … and then rebuild it. We have the technology.
sessions.title: SDK tools for performance

sessions.description: In the past, a student's college career was summed up with a transcript consisting of about 120 bits of information over 4 years. Today, information can be collected at a much faster rate, every minute the student is online. This session will describe how that information can be used to help students and educators improve the process, and how Google has experimented with online courses, to: (1) learn what material works and what can be improved; (2) evaluate a student's progress; and (3) inform the next generation of online courses.
sessions.title: Making sense of online course data

sessions.description: Build the best version of your app. Come learn tips and tricks for building truly great Android apps - get the most out of Android Studio’s design tools, master the intricacies of Gradle, tune your client performance with procstats and systrace, simplify your backend with Google Play services, and more. Android experts will be on hand to tear down your app … and then rebuild it. We have the technology.
sessions.title: SDK tools for layouts

sessions.description: Come and talk to our Google Play team.
sessions.title: Google Play office hours

sessions.description: Data delivered over an unencrypted channel is insecure, untrustworthy, and trivially intercepted. We must protect the security, privacy, and integrity of our users data. In this session we will take a hands-on tour of how to make your websites secure by default: the required technology, configuration and performance best practices, how to migrate your sites to HTTPS and make them user and search friendly, and more. Your users will thank you.
sessions.title: Secure by default

sessions.description:
Solve for X (www.solveforx.com) is a community of people working to accelerate progress on technology moonshots -- radical technology ideas for solving global problems. Radical in the sense that the solutions could help millions (or billions) of people; that the audacity of the proposals makes them sound like science fiction; and that there is some real breakthrough or new approach that makes us believe these ideas could be brought to life. We meet in-person and online. 

We’re running two special interactive Solve for X sessions at this year’s Google I/O.  After hearing short proposals from three tech pioneers, our audience will breakout into small-group brainstorming -- spending 2/3rds of the time generating ‘yes, and’ feedback (e.g. ideas for resources, funding, scaling), and 1/3rd of the time offering constructive critique (e.g. remaining questions, potential blind spots).  And then we gather to report back. 

Join us! 

Solve for X@IO - 3:00pm-5:00pm on the afternoon of June 25th.   
Solve for X@IO - 9:00am-11:00am on the morning of June 26th.

< Solve for X is an open platform powered by Google [x] and many partners and friends >
sessions.title: Solve for X - Accelerating moonshot projects

sessions.description: Meet with performance minded engineers for Unity Technologies! This session will present techniques for making high performance games for Android using Unity. Techniques will range from general tips for working with Unity to in depth CPU and GPU optimizations. Bring your Unity project and get expert help and hints on making the best games!
sessions.title: Unity tooling and performance

sessions.description: Over one billion people worldwide live with a disability and rely on technology for everyday services that many take for granted. Learn how to make your web and Android applications more accessible from experts who are leading Accessibility efforts at Google.
sessions.title: Introduction to Android accessibility

sessions.description: From the applications built by the thousands of Google Cast developers to our evolving ambient home screen experience, users have only seen a glimpse of the future of the living room.  Please join us as we give you more insight about the making of Chromecast, the vision for multi-screen devices, and the future of the Google Cast ecosystem.
sessions.title: Casting to the future

sessions.description: For decades Ray Kurzweil has explored how artificial intelligence can enrich and expand human capabilities. In his latest book, How To Create A Mind, he takes this exploration to the next step: reverse-engineering the brain to understand precisely how it works, then applying that knowledge to create intelligent machines. In the near term, Ray's project at Google is developing artificial intelligence based on biologically inspired models of the neocortex to enhance functions such as search, answering questions, interacting with the user, and language translation. The goal is to understand natural language to communicate with the user as well as to understand the meaning of web documents and books. In the long term, Ray believes it is only by extending our minds with our intelligent technology that we can overcome humanity’s grand challenges.
sessions.title: Biologically inspired models of intelligence

sessions.description: Now that App Engine is using Gradle in Android Studio, we'll go over how the gradle-appengine-plugin works and how to make it work for you.
sessions.title: Building App Engine with Gradle in Android Studio

sessions.description: Make your NDK app faster in real-time with performance optimization using Intel Graphics Performance Analyzers and Intel Vtune Amplifier. Intel's experts will be onsite, profiling real games and identifying performance opportunities.
sessions.title: Intel tooling and performance

sessions.description: In this session, we will talk about the exciting worlds of apps and search working together to deliver the best user experience possible.
sessions.title: The future of Apps and Search

sessions.description: Over one billion people worldwide live with a disability and rely on technology for everyday services that many take for granted. Learn how to make your web and Android applications more accessible from experts who are leading Accessibility efforts at Google.
sessions.title: Accessible web components

sessions.description: Walk right up, we're doing 480 minutes of demos on the latest of the web platform in Chrome. See the latest profiling advancements in the Chrome DevTools, explore cross-platform cross-compilation with pepper.js, the future of web development with Polymer and ramping you up on the latest best practices for successfully building for the mobile web.  Come by the booth if you want a few knowledge bombs and talk to Chrome team engineers who can help you improve how you develop for the web.
sessions.title: 10 things I learned from the Chrome OS source

sessions.description: Meet the Google Wallet team and learn how to build a great mobile commerce app.
sessions.title: Saving time and money with Google Wallet office hours

sessions.description: Walk right up, we're doing 480 minutes of demos on the latest of the web platform in Chrome. See the latest profiling advancements in the Chrome DevTools, explore cross-platform cross-compilation with pepper.js, the future of web development with Polymer and ramping you up on the latest best practices for successfully building for the mobile web.  Come by the booth if you want a few knowledge bombs and talk to Chrome team engineers who can help you improve how you develop for the web.
sessions.title: Optimizing for the user experience with WebPagetest

sessions.description: Build the best version of your app. Come learn tips and tricks for building truly great Android apps - get the most out of Android Studio’s design tools, master the intricacies of Gradle, tune your client performance with procstats and systrace, simplify your backend with Google Play services, and more. Android experts will be on hand to tear down your app … and then rebuild it. We have the technology.
sessions.title: Renderscript

sessions.description: You built an app. Awesome. Do you have a monetization plan? An easy way for your users to pay? Does anyone know about it? How are you tracking success? In addition to providing the platforms and tools to design and develop your apps, we also have solutions to help make it discoverable and more profitable. Learn how you can turn your app into a business by understanding your most valuable users, finding more of them, and tailoring the monetization experience for each different group. We can also help enable fast and seamless transactions so users can purchase products or services in your app.
sessions.title: Maximize app engagement, monetization and distribution

sessions.description: This workshop is for developers who want to become part of the design story. It's a starting point, and it will take them thru creating designs that are focused on UX & !UI, and also learn to empathize w/ their users (and internalize the user centric design process), in order to create apps that users love! Capacity: 100 people.
sessions.title: Build better products, not more features: UX design for developers

sessions.description:
App developers ask themselves excellent questions about their users: Do people need my app? Can people use my app? Why do people sign up and then not use my app? However, app developers answer their excellent questions in invalid and unreliable ways. It is shocking to see how much effort app developers put in writing elegantly structured, refactored code, with good unit test coverage in an agile environment, and yet, their apps fail miserably. 

This talk will inspire developers to implement valid and reliable ways to answer their most burning questions. It’ll help them validate or invalidate their assumptions on their own—cheaply, and quickly, by using simple user research techniques with a main goal in mind: developing apps people need, want, and enjoy.
sessions.title: Perfectly executing the wrong plan

sessions.description: Motion sensors on smartphones can be used to create amazing user experiences, such as 360 degree viewing of content (Spotlight Stories, StreetView panoramas, Photo spheres, etc.) or intuitive panoramic image capture. In this session, we demonstrate a range of interesting new experiences and give a deep dive into the underlying technical principles. We discuss sensor fusion on Android, creation and rendering of content, and user interaction fundamentals.
sessions.title: Field of view

sessions.description:
Solve for X (www.solveforx.com) is a community of people working to accelerate progress on technology moonshots -- radical technology ideas for solving global problems. Radical in the sense that the solutions could help millions (or billions) of people; that the audacity of the proposals makes them sound like science fiction; and that there is some real breakthrough or new approach that makes us believe these ideas could be brought to life. We meet in-person and online. 

We’re running two special interactive Solve for X sessions at this year’s Google I/O.  After hearing short proposals from three tech pioneers, our audience will breakout into small-group brainstorming -- spending 2/3rds of the time generating ‘yes, and’ feedback (e.g. ideas for resources, funding, scaling), and 1/3rd of the time offering constructive critique (e.g. remaining questions, potential blind spots).  And then we gather to report back. 

Join us! 

Solve for X@IO - 3:00pm-5:00pm on the afternoon of June 25th.   
Solve for X@IO - 9:00am-11:00am on the morning of June 26th.

< Solve for X is an open platform powered by Google [x] and many partners and friends >
sessions.title: Solve for X - Accelerating moonshot projects

sessions.description: See how the flexibility and expressiveness of open-source data processing/analytics software can be mixed and matched seamlessly on Google Cloud Platform. With the help of our connectors and tools for interoperability across several Google Cloud products, you'll be able to select the right tool(s) for the right jobs as they come.

sessions.description: Take a developer's tour of the Android Wear platform and Google's new wearable APIs. Learn about our simple and powerful tools for creating apps for Android Wear devices and bringing wearable experiences to your Android apps. We'll walk step-by-step through designing and building a small, contextual app for Android Wear.

sessions.description:
Making sense of your Big Data problems doesn't have to require a herculean effort. Deriving meaning from your data, at any scale, doesn't have to involve a tangle of clusters, configurations, and scripts that takes a team of specialized administrators to unravel. In fact, you can make it manageable and easy for all developers without losing insight in the process. We've created easy-to-use services so that you can run deep analytics on both streaming and historical data with as little effort as hosting an app on App Engine. 

However, sometimes, you need more control and configurability than managed services allow. That doesn't mean that you lose all the benefits of the Big Data tools that Google Cloud Platform has developed. You can easily combine managed services, where it makes sense, with Open Source tools like Hadoop and Spark. This session will dive into what you can use today to manage Big Data like Google itself does, “the Cloud way”, as well as how you can plan to scale as your data needs shift and mature.
sessions.title: Big data, the Cloud way: Accelerated and simplified

sessions.description: Not sure how to organizer your Go projects? Trapped in a maze of twisty dependencies, all alike? In this session we'll look at some practical examples of how to organize Go code into packages and how to manage third party dependencies for distribution and deployment.

sessions.description:
Wearable computing is here and the way we interact with technology will be completely different.  Building cool, fun, and delightful experiences is no longer enough.  They must also be experiences that address specific user problems and never get in the way or take precedence over the user's life.  They must give users all the benefits of technology they've come to expect, and more, while meeting them on their terms in a seamless and intrinsically human way.

In this session, we'll take a look at the constellation of devices that make up not just wearable, but ubiquitous computing.  We'll tie them all together with common design and development practices as well as the Google Platform.  This is the key information that'll get you ready for being part of a sea change of technology that invariably puts the user first.
sessions.title: Wearable computing with Google

sessions.description:
It doesn’t matter if you’re writing a multiplayer Android game, or a simple to-do app, your users are increasingly expanding multi-device access from anywhere.    However, sharing state from highscore lists to to-do lists between devices in a way that works well with spotty network connections is hard, error prone and expensive.   Wouldn’t it be great if Google took care of all that, while providing an easy path to expand as your app grows and matures?   

In this session, we will show you how to build mobile apps which use new Google technology to simplify data storage, online/offline behavior and synchronization across multiple devices. You’ll have full access to the data you store in the Google Cloud platform with app development features and the rich set of data analytics tools to get more use out of your data.   You’ll see how Android Studio tooling makes this straightforward, and allows you to bring the full power of Google Cloud Platform to your app as your needs grow. Come away equipped with new tools and skills to make your app better than ever, without writing hundreds of lines of code.

- Get more of your content in Google Search
- Drive more Android app installs
- Automatically sign in users across devices
- Generate user notifications that appear across Google properties
- And more!

Developers around the world are building new tools to help people stay safe during crises, engage with their communities and governments, and more effectively receive public services. What started as hobbies and hackathon projects have evolved into sustainable businesses that serve millions of users around the globe. These tools rely on open data about our societies, governments and physical world, but transform it and make it useful.

Our partner developers around the globe are making people safer and reinvigorating democracies with technology. This presentation will explore the motivations, technologies and challenges behind Google's work with these partners, as well as share what we've learned about how anyone can use their unique skills to make a difference.

sessions.description: Many websites still provide a poor experience on mobile, and so we wanted to develop an in-depth understanding of what differentiates a great and an inferior mobile experience. Our work has resulted in the development of a set of user experience principles for mobile website design. The principles illustrate how to create experiences that support conversion on mobile, whether that be for a purchase, a quote or a lead. The principles have been developed out of a study that Google User Experience Research conducted in partnership with AnswerLab - a user research consultancy. We studied 100 sites with diversity across size and vertical, and held 119 in-person, one-hour usability sessions with Android and iOS smartphone users. We instructed participants to perform key conversion-focused tasks, such as purchasing an item, booking a reservation, or researching plans or prices.  This presentation will illustrate key principles for designing a better mobile web.
sessions.title: Design principles for a better mobile web

sessions.description: If you are collecting access logs from 100 web servers with >100K req/s, how do you draw a graph of req/s from the logs for last 12 months and update it every 3 sec? You'd need a design pattern called "Lambda Architecture", a combination of real-time and big data processing. In this session, we will show how you can take advantage of the power of Docker to deploy a large scale LA in 10 min with BigQuery and Complex Event Processing (CEP) tool.

We’ve worked with developers to make it even easier to integrate and monetize physical goods and services on Android. We’ve listened to buyers and have made using Instant Buy a simpler experience.
